newsitem.title: USA: Calif. picks brokers for big utility bond deal.
newsitem.headline: Calif. picks brokers for big utility bond deal.

text.p: California's treasurer said Wednesday he tapped Lehman Brothers, Morgan Stanley and Salomon Brothers to underwrite the upcoming sale of up to $6 billion of bonds as part of the state's plan to deregulate its electricity market.
State Treasurer Matt Fong said Lehman would serve as co-senior manager, along with Morgan Stanley and Salomon Brothers, for the so-called "rate reduction bonds" that will be sold later this year.
The bonds will be sold on behalf of PG&E Corp's Pacific Gas & Electric Co, Edison International's Southern California Edison Co, and Enova Corp's San Diego Gas & Electric Co.
The bonds will help offset the so-called stranded costs facing the utilities, such as nuclear power plants that would not be economical in a competitive market.
Fong said the bonds would also allow the utilities to provide customers a 10 percent rate reduction.
The bonds are a critical part of California's plan to throw open its $20 billion electricity market to competition next January, state officials said.
"These bonds are an important part of a deregulation process that will result in lower utility costs for Californians," Fong said in a statement.

Fong's office said Lehman Brothers and Morgan Stanley would handle the Pacific Gas & Electric and San Diego Gas & Electric bonds; Lehman and Salomon Brothers would handle the Southern California Edison issue.
Up to $6 billion of the bonda will be issued by the state infrastructure bank later this year, Fong's office said.
